reasoning: The critique targets the position’s (continued) use of a CES-style, time-invariant substitutability parameter ρ to derive ‘max speed’ ceilings and early-vs-late stage implications. That’s fairly central to the post’s quantitative/sensitivity-analysis reasoning about when compute bottlenecks bite, though less central to the broader qualitative claim that naive economic estimates are a weak prior (which the post itself already partially concedes via Jones-style “production function changes” and extrapolation caveats). The objection has moderate force: AI R&D progress is dynamic and path-dependent, so a static CES mapping from (L,K) to a progress rate is not automatically justified, and treating a fixed ρ as informative can be question-begging. However it doesn’t fully refute the approach, since one can still use CES as a local/short-run approximation or embed it within a dynamic model; calling it a categorical failure somewhat overstates the case. The critique is mostly correct, clear, tightly focused, and contains little dead weight.
title: A static CES production function cannot bound dynamic, path-dependent algorithmic progress
